title: 111_s3936
content: The "States as Energy Leaders for the Future Act" or "SELF Act" defines terms like "eligible entity" and "Secretary" for the Clean Energy Grant Program. The Department of Energy established a program to provide grants to eligible entities for clean energy and carbon reduction measures, including renewable electricity standards, climate action plans, use of alternative fuel vehicles, energy efficiency in public buildings, and participation in greenhouse gas reduction programs. The eligible entity can receive grants for various clean energy initiatives, such as energy efficiency standards, participation in greenhouse gas reduction programs, on-bill financing for energy improvements, State tax incentives for clean energy components, innovative financing mechanisms, and best management practices. To be eligible for a grant under this section, a State or local government, or a regional consortium, must meet requirements set by the Secretary and partner with private sector and nongovernmental organizations. The grant can be used for clean energy initiatives like energy efficiency standards, grid technology improvement, and implementation of carbon efficiency standards. The Secretary will determine grant recipients based on applications submitted by eligible entities and criteria established by regulation. The Secretary will issue regulations establishing criteria for grants under this section, specifying eligible measures, application criteria, and development. Grant funds must be used for eligible purposes as determined by the Secretary. The Secretary will develop regulations for grants, including specifying eligible measures, application criteria, and a point system for reviewing applications. Considerations include regional energy disparities and clean energy potential. The Secretary will publish an explanation in the Federal Register on how grants awarded under the Act will ensure an objective evaluation based on specified criteria. Authorization of $5 billion for fiscal year 2011 to carry out the Act, with funds remaining available until expended. Cost offset for clean energy grant program and deficit reduction by denying deduction for major integrated oil companies. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes a provision for major integrated oil companies to qualify for oil-related production activities. This is a conforming amendment to ensure consistency within the code. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows major integrated oil companies to qualify for oil-related production activities, with an effective date for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010.
